newsitem.title: USA: BASEBALL-JOHNSON STRIKES BACK WITH GAME-WINNING HIT.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-JOHNSON STRIKES BACK WITH GAME-WINNING HIT.

text.p: Mark Johnson's pinch-hit single with one out in the bottom of the 10th inning scored Jason Kendall with the winning run to give the surprising Pirates a 5-4 win Friday over the Philadelphia Phillies.

Johnson, ripped in a Pittsburgh newspaper column earlier in the day for his weak 2-for-24 stretch at the plate, batted for Freddy Garcia and lined a Ricky Bottalico pitch down the line in right for the winning run.
"It's as good a win as we had this year," said manager Gene Lamont, whose low-budget Pirates are in first place in the Central Division with a 30-29 record.
"I guess when a guy takes a beating in the paper, it's tough on the whole team. To throw it back in the face of the people that do it is really nice."
Said Johnson: "I guess I'm just going to keep battling. It seems I've been the focus lately. It was a situation where I knew I had to come through."
Pittsburgh starter Francisco Cordova carried a shutout into the eighth inning, but the Phillies erupted for four runs to tie the game.
Marc Wilkins, the fourth Pittsburgh pitcher, got the win to improve to 5-0. Jerry Spradlin (1-2) took the loss for the hapless Phils, who have lost seven of their last eight games.
In Los Angeles, Ray Lankford hit a pair of solo homers and Ron Gant hit another to back the strong pitching of Alan Benes as the St. Louis Cardinals took a 3-1 win over the Dodgers.
Benes (5-5) rebounded from last Sunday's 6-1 loss to the Dodgers, holding them to seven hits in eight innings and striking out seven. Dennis Eckersley worked a perfect ninth inning for his 12th save.
Chan Ho Park (4-3), who beat the Cardinals last Sunday, allowed three runs and seven hits over seven innings and took the loss.
In San Diego, the Houston Astros zoomed out to a 7-0 lead after four innings then held on to defeat the Padres 8-7.

San Diego battled back with six runs in the fifth to pull within 7-6, but Jeff Bagwell hit a solo homer in the sixth -- his league leading 19th homer -- for a key insurance run as Houston stayed a half-game behind the Pirates in the Central.
"It was nice because they had come back and that tacked on another," Bagwell said of the homer. "You look back and you think you probably should've lost the game."
Jose Lima (1-3) picked up his first National League victory. Padres starter Joey Hamilton (4-3) was the loser.
Houston has won four of its last five games.
In Montreal, Jim Bullinger pitched a six-hitter against his former team and Henry Rodriguez homered as the Montreal Expos stopped a three-game losing streak with a 3-0 win over the Chicago Cubs.
Bullinger (3-5) is 2-1 in three starts against his former team this season. "A win in this league is pretty hard to come by, so they're all pretty special," said Bullinger.
Chicago's best scoring chance came in the seventh after a pair of one-out singles. But pinch-hitter Dave Clark grounded into a double play.
"It's no lie when they say those are a pitcher's best friend," Bullinger said about the twin killing.

In San Francisco, Javy Lopez homered, doubled and drove in three runs, and five relievers combined to allow one unearned run over the final 6 2/3 innings to lead the Atlanta Braves to a 9-5 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
Tony Graffanino went 3-for-4 and Andruw Jones and Michael Tucker each had two hits for the Braves, who banged out 15 hits.
In Cincinnati, Brett Tomko tossed six strong innings to notch his first major-league win and recorded his first hit and RBI in the process as the Cincinnati Reds finally beat the New York Mets, 5-2.
Tomko (1-1), called up to replace the injured John Smiley, allowed one run and four hits as the Reds beat the Mets for the first time in five meetings.
Rick Reed (4-3) had his worst outing of the season for the Mets, surrendering five runs and nine hits in six innings.
At Colorado, the Rockies' game against the Florida Marlines was postponed because of rain.
